sourceDesc.bibl: Birth Control: Mrs. Sanger's Address at Bangalore, The Hindu, Jan. 18, 1936

headNote.p: Sanger gave this speech to the South Indian Science Association at the Central College in Bangalore, India. Sastra Vaidya Pravine, and S. Subba Rao presided. The speech was not found.

docBody.head: Birth Control
Mrs. Sanger's Address at Bangalore
docBody.p: “To you in India who have given to the world marvelous temples that have been built by your great men in the past and handed on to us (westerners) to admire- and we do admire them- the time is now come to make another kind of temple, the ‘human temple’ and the ‘human body.’ Let us begin to make our bodies fit and perfect instruments to house that soul that we may summon to take its place in the mystery of human beings.” In these words, Mrs. Margaret Sanger, birth control exponent from America who is now on a tour in India, put forth a plea before a Bangalore audience tonight for the practice of birth control.

p.q: The meeting was held at the Central College, under the auspices of the South Indian Science Association and was presided over by Sastra Vaidya Pravina Dr. S. Subba Rao, Senior Surgeon in Mysore.

Mrs. Margaret Sanger said that birth control was the key-not of a new moral and spiritual awakening. It was not only a health or economic expedient. It was a moral and social principle. That principle was interlocked with the spiritual advancement of nations and with the race as well.

Many British Bishops and clergymen, Mrs. Sanger said, had been pleading for some time past that the members of the Christian faith should come forth and lead the movement so that it might be a constructive force in civilization and not to close their eyes and ears to its human appeal.
